Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the parent needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story: I woke up early, my mind already racing with numbers. The home loan repayment loomed over me, just two months away, and I needed every spare dollar to make sure we didn’t fall behind. As a parent, I felt the weight of responsibility pressing on my chest—my kids depended on me to keep our home safe and secure. I’d planned to spend the day reviewing our finances, maybe even picking up a few extra hours at work if I could. But today was also election day. The polling station was open all day, and my schedule was light, so there was really no excuse not to go. Still, every minute away from my financial planning felt like a risk. I could hear my children laughing in the next room, and I knew what was at stake. Yet, as a citizen, I felt the pull of duty—my vote mattered, and I wanted to set an example for my kids about civic responsibility. The expectations tugged at me from both sides, and I sat at the kitchen table, paralyzed by the impossible choice between my family’s immediate needs and my role in shaping our future.
